title: Footy star Kurtley Beale is almost taken down by a streaker at Rugby World Cup match
text:
Kurtley Beale has narrowly avoided being taken down by a streaker during a Rugby World Cup match.

The pitch intruder, who was wearing only a Wallabies-branded kimono and sneakers, tried to high-five the Beale in the 75th minute of Australia's 45-10 win over Uruguay at Oita Stadium in Japan on Saturday.

Beale admitted the intrusion caught him 'by surprise' but he later laughed it off, saying 'he got me really good'.

The streaker, believed to be Australian, was reportedly arrested after returning to the stadium concourse.

Footy star Kurtley Beale (right) has narrowly avoided being taken down by a streaker (left) during the Australia-Uruguay Rugby World Cup match

The male intruder, who was only wearing a Wallabies shirt and sneakers, tried to high-five the fullback in the 75th minute of Australia's 45-10 win at Oita Stadium, Japan

'I heard the crowd cheering and I thought, ''What is going on? Are they cheering because of the ruck? The ball is just in the ruck'',' Beale said.

'Then all of a sudden I felt something come over my left shoulder and he came up and he spooked me.

'I don't think he got caught, he went back into the stands and enjoyed the rest of the game.'

Beale, along with multiple footy fans, joked about the situation on social media

Beale, along with multiple footy fans, joked about the situation on social media.

'I'm afraid there wasn't much to tackle,' he said on Twitter in response to a tweet from Fox Sports Rugby who said the incident was a 'missed tackle' by Beale.

'Just nuts,' one fan joked.

'An opportunity to introduce some Australian culture to the Japanese,' another wrote.

One added: 'Definitely don't want to choke tackle it.'

Beale (pictured with girlfriend Maddi Blomberg) admitted the nudist caught him 'by surprise' but laughed off the incident saying 'he got me really good'

A Rugby World Cup spokesperson confirmed to the Sydney Morning Herald the streaker had been confronted by authorities.

'The spectator was able to re-enter the seating bowl and was subsequently arrested by police on the stadium concourse,' the spokesperson said.

'The spectator is currently in police custody.'

Staff at the World Cup said any person who accesses the field without authorisation risks having their ticket cancelled and will be handed over to police.

The act is an offence in Japan and is punishable by law.
